data: Cultural Role-Play in England in Arthurian Mythology

The project "Experience of Cultural Role-Play in England" is a training course for youth workers that is planned with the intention of spreading and further developing the European Roleplay Approach (ERA), an extremely successful learning approach that uses a role-playing game as a framework to teach a variety of skills, such as intercultural skills, social skills, communication skills, language skills, teamwork, creativity, leadership skills etc. Role-playing is seen as a framework that motivates and activates young people and opens their minds for learning. 
The training course focuses on how to build the framework and connect the desired learning content with the game-based learning approach. The approach uses an immersive game that introduces young people to a stealth learning setting. The course is focused on preparing youth workers for implementing ERA (European Roleplay Approach).
At the same time the project partners see the project as a way to try out spreading the role-playing methods through a training course (since they have never done it before) and benefit from exchanging experiences between different countries. 
The partners are very active in creating and developing game approaches for young people and have run three youth exchange events in which they used ERA and focused on intercultural learning. The overwhelming success and high demand have encouraged the partners to explore the learning through role-playing approach further.
The approach is used as a game that runs over several hours. Youths create heroes who attempt to accomplish tasks in an exciting setting, often set in the cultural background of a certain country. For instance, in the youth events we have tried a Norse mythology background, a Greek mythology background, and a Sami mythology background. Since different heroes have different skills and knowledge, cooperation is the key to overcoming the obstacles and successfully completing the game. Youth workers usually have the role of preparing the adventure in advance and take on the role of game directors during the event. They  describe the adventure as a story in which the players, working in teams, can decide what their heroes do and say, so that they influence the direction of the storyline. The game can be played both inside and outside, making it possible for the teams to go on long walks and play in nature. The game does not involve computers, and it is designed on purpose to get youths away from computers and engage in social dialogue.
In this event the focus will lie on the Arthurian Legends and the value system. The game world will be a world of valiant knights who keep the country safe from harm which is a great setting to explore values of society and create conflicts through the game which touch on the personal value systems of youths. For instance, the question of honour can be raised when honour becomes the source of conflicts.
Training Course: Intercultural Values in Grimm's Fairy Tales

The project “Intercultural Values in Grimms Fairytales” is a training course for youth workers which aims to spread and continue to develop the European Roleplay Approach (ERA), a tested and successful learning approach using role playing games as a framework to teach a variety of skills, such as intercultural skills, social skills, communication skills, language skills, teamwork, creativity, leaderships skills, to name just a few. Role-playing is a framework that motivates and activates young people, and opens their minds for learning. This training course teaches how to build the framework and connect the desired learning content with the game-based learning approach. The basis of the approach is to use an immersive game that introduces youths to a stealth learning approach. The course is focused on preparing youth workers for using ERA (European Roleplay Approach) in their own youth work.
The partners are very active in creating and developing game approaches for young people and have run several youth exchange events in which they used ERA and focused on intercultural learning. The overwhelming success and high demand have encouraged the partners to continue exploring the learning through role-playing approach further.
The approach is used as a game that runs over several hours. Youths create heroes who attempt to accomplish tasks in an exciting setting, often set in the cultural background of a certain country. For instance, in previous youth events we have used a Norse mythology background, a Greek mythology background, and a Sami mythology background. Since different heroes have different skills and knowledge, cooperation is the key to overcoming the obstacles and successfully completing the game. Youth workers usually have the role of preparing the adventure in advance and take on the role of game directors during the event. They describe the adventure as a story in which the players, working in teams, can decide what their heroes do and say, so that they influence the direction of the storyline. The game can be played both inside and outside, making it possible for the teams to go on long walks and play in nature. The game does not involve computers, and it is designed on purpose to let youths get away from computers and engage in social dialogue.
In this event youth workers will learn how to immerse their youths in the creepy and mysterious world of Grimms Fairytales. By exploring and turning around the fairy tales (the players must make sure the essential part of the fairytale happens) we are able to explore many relevant themes, such as overcoming social and physical obstacles, finding inner courage, survival in a dangerous world, and the effects and consequences of ethical behavior. The fun and relaxed atmosphere of the fairy tales allows the players to reflect on their personal values and explore the values of others.
